body: LGTM.

15 TC inspections failed, seemingly spuriously. Restarted that checker. Alternatively, we could just merge this without inspections passing, since nothing changed in this patch that should affect inspections anyway.
It's fixed in 0.11 by #4745
@gianm thanks, closing it then.

:+1:
a little late to review but we deployed this patch and can confirm that it fixes the problem mentioned in https://github.com/druid-io/druid/pull/4973#issuecomment-342958133
@himanshug Can you do the backport of this?
@jon-wei thanks. https://github.com/druid-io/druid/pull/5068
Fixed by #5037.

@leventov seems like the weird error is due to this part:

```
error reading /home/travis/.m2/repository/org/apache/hadoop/hadoop-hdfs/2.7.3/hadoop-hdfs-2.7.3-tests.jar; error in opening zip file
```

The `hadoop-hdfs-2.7.3-tests.jar` could be corrupt. The corruption could persist across builds due to the cache, enabled in our .travis.yml here:

```
cache:
  directories:
    - $HOME/.m2
```

Clearing the cache could help (https://docs.travis-ci.com/user/caching/).
@himanshug cool, I added a note to the 0.11.0 release notes in "Upgrading coordinators and overlords" regarding the incompatibilities, can you review that section?
@nishantmonu51 could you please fix conflicts
@jon-wei changed slightly to make it clear that overlords and coordinators can be upgraded indepedent of each other. thanks.

:+1: aside from minor comment
@egor-ryashin have you tested this by introducing an artificial test error in integration test build to make it fail and see the logs produced in build logs? it would be nice to check that things work as expected.
@gianm thanks for creating those backports
@leventov no problem; I have a script to do it so it's pretty easy :)
Yes, that will work. It will be great to support more databases then.

Hi drcrallen,
As your suggestion, I add below setting in middleManager/runtime.properties and it works for me:
druid.monitoring.monitors=["io.druid.client.cache.CacheMonitor","com.metamx.metrics.JvmMonitor"]

Thanks for your advice and it resolves my problem. I agree with you and we do not need to change the source code.
Cool thanks for checking!
@gianm thanks
@gianm could you please fix compilation
@drcrallen would you fix the conflicts? I'll review soon.
@leventov should be fixed now

I think the author wanted to say: different properties than the indexing services. 
Historically Druid has _standalone real-time_ nodes to pull data from Kafka, this type of node is not used anymore.
@himanshug Yes, tested with error, the output is ok.
@egor-ryashin thanks for checking.
@gianm can you share your script ?
@nishantmonu51 can you please update the PR description?

@himanshug it's https://gist.github.com/gianm/68145b09a55e6f6460a11ae9adfc25a4

For some reason the "milestone" and "labels" never get set, I'm not sure what's wrong there. If you ever figure it out let me know how to fix it :)

that makes sense.

This doc continues on to talk about stream-pull as standalone real-time nodes. Is this page then totally obsolete and should be removed or marked as obsolete with the last relevant version, or is it still relevant, just the implementation has changed?
@dyanarose totally agree with you druid docs need a massive revamp/restructure especially the real-time ingestion section.

hah, brilliant. Until someone else comes along, I'll see about starting that particularly hairy conversation.

Ta @b-slim, I'll close this out now
Mind if I pick this up? I want to contribute.

Any update on this?

I'm not super familiar with Dropwizard, so I may be conflating things, but I know Kafka uses Dropwizard's metrics library internally, and that's a pretty battle-tested piece of software. So it'd be nice to see this in Druid as well as it'd be very convenient to emit these metrics over JMX/StatsD, etc.

--- *[processing/src/main/java/io/druid/segment/StringDimensionIndexer.java, line 61 at r1](https://reviewable.io:443/reviews/druid-io/druid/4754#-KycL2Hmt325XnW8ey4L:-KycL2Hmt325XnW8ey4M:b-izu3ec) ([raw file](https://github.com/druid-io/druid/blob/35291a6d12ec53ba09339bffae430785da6d89f9/processing/src/main/java/io/druid/segment/StringDimensionIndexer.java#L61)):* > ```Java > public class StringDimensionIndexer implements DimensionIndexer > { > private static final Function STRING_TRANSFORMER = o -> o != null > ``` `STRING_TRANSFORMER` is very generic how about renaming it to something like `emptyToNullIfNullabilityON` --- *[processing/src/main/java/io/druid/segment/transform/TransformSpec.java, line 42 at r1](https://reviewable.io:443/reviews/druid-io/druid/4754#-KyccyJ0p7IXSjKAWYrd:-KyccyJ0p7IXSjKAWYre:b4i3j2s) ([raw file](https://github.com/druid-io/druid/blob/35291a6d12ec53ba09339bffae430785da6d89f9/processing/src/main/java/io/druid/segment/transform/TransformSpec.java#L42)):* > ```Java > * input rows) and "transforms" (which can add fields to input rows). Filters may refer to fields generated by > * a transform. > *

> ``` this PR has enough lines to review not sure why are we adding this :smile: --- *[processing/src/test/java/io/druid/segment/TestHelper.java, line 331 at r1](https://reviewable.io:443/reviews/druid-io/druid/4754#-Kyca1Mi8iUKAbJnB9AS:-Kyca1Mi8iUKAbJnB9AT:bwzhyqn) ([raw file](https://github.com/druid-io/druid/blob/35291a6d12ec53ba09339bffae430785da6d89f9/processing/src/test/java/io/druid/segment/TestHelper.java#L331)):* > ```Java > ((Number) expectedValue).doubleValue(), > ((Number) actualValue).doubleValue(), > ((Number) expectedValue).doubleValue() * 1e-6 > ``` we are we removing abs here? is it used when the expected value is negative thought. --- *[processing/src/test/java/io/druid/segment/TestHelper.java, line 345 at r1](https://reviewable.io:443/reviews/druid-io/druid/4754#-KycarO1HgC-AfMS71SH:-KycarO1HgC-AfMS71SI:bti24hf) ([raw file](https://github.com/druid-io/druid/blob/35291a6d12ec53ba09339bffae430785da6d89f9/processing/src/test/java/io/druid/segment/TestHelper.java#L345)):* > ```Java > > > public static Map createExpectedMap(Object... vals) > ``` The name of this method is not very informative how about tuning it into a map builder style? or maybe use `java.util.Collections.UnmodifiableMap` --- *Comments from [Reviewable](https://reviewable.io:443/reviews/druid-io/druid/4754)*
may be backport ?
Hmm weird. Looks there is another issue.
cc @drcrallen
@rahulsingh303 Did you figure out what was the issue? I'm facing same problem. :I

CI just failed with the same error:
```
io.druid.curator.announcement.AnnouncerTest
testSanity(io.druid.curator.announcement.AnnouncerTest)  Time elapsed: 61.104 sec  <<< ERROR!
java.lang.Exception: test timed out after 60000 milliseconds
	at sun.misc.Unsafe.park(Native Method)

Oops, the test still failed. I guess I won't merge this yet.
Adding this to 0.11.0 milestone, I think it'd be good to get this in before we release the first official version with the security interfaces, to avoid disruption for extension implementers.

@pjain1 could this be moved to 0.11.1? It doesn't seem like a regression fix or something that critically needs to be in 0.11.0. So I'd rather avoid delaying 0.11.0.

Although if there is a reason I'm missing please call it out.
@jon-wei there's a conflict here now.
0.11.1 is fine

I would like to get this into 0.11.0 as well, this isn't a "bug" but I think authenticator extension implementers are likely to run into similar circular dependency issues if they have intra-cluster communication requirements during authenticator initialization, and it would nice to have that addressed in the initial interface release
@gianm fixed conflict
resumed in https://github.com/druid-io/druid/pull/4815
Closing in favor of #4815

> @gianm @dclim my only request is to prioritize this in the reviews so that it gets merged as early as possible. thanks.

Sure thing, we will prioritize reviewing it along with the Kafka incremental publishing patch.
@gianm thanks.
It might be good idea to take a deeper look into Announcer class and make sure that it doesn't have a bug instead of test.

>         final int id = valueToId.getInt(value);
>         return id < 0 ? ABSENT_VALUE_ID : id;

*Comments from [Reviewable](https://reviewable.io:443/reviews/druid-io/druid/4754)*
<!-- Sent from Reviewable.io -->
@gianm Can you please review this pr or please assign it to someone who can review this PR. This PR is already been reviewed by @himanshug .
Sorry for the delay @akashdw I am taking another look now.
@akashdw looks good to me after conflicts are fixed.
:+1: once https://github.com/druid-io/druid/pull/5073#discussion_r150695602 is resolved .
still LGTM ... good to merge once build is done.

Thanks guys for the review.

I think there might be several issues beyond this failure. I could reproduce this timeout failure with a lazy executorService which sleeps for 10 secs before every ```execute()``` call, and, in this case, it was because of the missing ```CHILD_REMOVED``` event described above.

I also checked Announcer, but couldn't find any race condition. Even if it has a race condition, I bet it does not relate to this timeout issue because AnnouncerTest is essentially single-threaded. For all operations executed in background (write on ZK), it immediately checks the result of those operations or waits for them to be finished using latch. 

However, yeah, it still fails sometimes. I'm not sure why this happens.
I'm testing this patch by running travis CI multiple times. Hopefully this patch helps to reduce the timeout failure.

Reviewed 17 of 298 files at r1.
Review status: all files reviewed at latest revision, 14 unresolved discussions, some commit checks failed.

---



*Comments from [Reviewable](https://reviewable.io:443/reviews/druid-io/druid/4754)*
<!-- Sent from Reviewable.io -->
@pjain1 sorry for delay. There were some problems in our cluster last week, and I couldn't test your patch properly. I'll test and let you know the result soon.

The test looks being passed after adding a travis job for server module test. I feel the time when most travis builds fail is 09:00 PDT, so I will run more travis builds for this patch during that time.
@pjain1 I tested this patch on our cluster and it looks working well with small ```maxRowsPerSegment```. Nice work!
@gianm is there a path to getting this reviewed and merged?
Thanks @zhangxinyu1, do you want to make a pull-request to fix this?

> Disabling broker caching is somewhat common, since enabling the broker cache prevents historicals from fully merging their results (they need to send them by-segment to the broker).

@gianm why retrieving cached results on brokers prevents historicals from sending merged results?

> so you don't want to avoid get on cache altogether and in case of hybrid cache still wanna check in L1 . given that 99% of time you have cache miss, I'm not sure how much benefit is there.

@himanshug the cache key could be evicted from memcached, but stay in local cache on a historical. Broker gives you "survival bias" only about the first.
@jacob-koren thanks for contribution. Could you please make a PR against `master`, not `0.9.2` branch? We don't support old branches anyway.

I actually think that this issue should be reopened. What if we remove support for ZooKeeper coordination and replace it completely with Consul? We could also piggy-back it's key-value store for indexer locks.

I am all for it! We are running consul in production for a good year now, it sneaked in "well, let's deploy and see how it goes" to "consul keeps the lights on". It's orders of magnitude better than zookeeper.

> @gianm why retrieving cached results on brokers prevents historicals from sending merged results?

It doesn't, but populating the cache does. If the broker is only reading the cache, but not populating it, then historicals can send merged results. But of course that means it has to be reading the populated cache from somewhere else -- presumably memcached populated by historicals.
@gianm yes, that is what I meant in https://github.com/druid-io/druid/issues/4947#issuecomment-336007722
Understood, that makes sense
@leventov  @kaijianding  @jihoonson How do you think the design of `multiValueDelimiter `?
@leventov  Yes, could you please review [this pull-request](https://github.com/druid-io/druid/pull/5089/files)
@zhangxinyu1 thanks. please fix checkstyle
@leventov thanks, I have fixed it.

@jacob-koren it's important to retain the job properties in the json, otherwise they cannot be sent down to the cluster. Perhaps a better approach would be masking known sensitive properties, like GuiceRunnable does when the CLI starts up.
@zhangxinyu1 Have you seen this issue in the wild, and if so what error message gets reported? Could you write a test that reproduces the problem and verifies the fix?
@leventov would you please have a look for this pr? thx

Hi @gianm 

Thanks for pointing out. I've removed one exclusion for the test scope and it seems to work again. Right now I'm stuck at the flakey test again. Do you have any tricks to get that one passing?

Cheers, Fokko
How did you fix this?

> I see you've worked on making the RealtimePlumber use a SegmentAllocator rather than come up with its own identifiers.

Yep, the main reason here is to allow the `RealtimeIndexTask` to append data to existing intervals and allow for late arriving data, similar to how the kafka indexing service works

> As an alternate approach did you look at trying to make the RealtimeIndexTask use an AppenderatorDriver rather than a Plumber? The Appenderator system is a bit newer and I was hoping that it would eventually replace Plumbers. They should be just as capable. It should also reduce the need for refactoring anything outside of RealtimeIndexTask.

I did look at that, specifically the `AppenderatorPlumber`.  I opted not to use it because it wasn't really being used in any of the existing code paths and since I'm not as familiar with the code base, I thought it best to use the code thats been battle-tested, so to speak

> The main issue I was thinking of with that approach is that the on-disk directory structures aren't exactly the same, so that would affect the ability of tasks to restore. I think it should be ok if it's just one time, though. If we really felt strongly about preserving the ability to restore across the upgrade, then I guess the task could peek at its on-disk structure and migrate it if needed.

Are you saying that the on-disk directory structures between the RealtimePlumber and the `AppenderatorDriver` are different?  

I don't have a strong opinion on whats best here in terms of preserving that so I'll defer to you on that.
I bet this could be fixed by switching to groupBy v2 (which is the default now anyway)
Yeah, we actually switched back to v1 because we couldn't get v2 to perform. Would you mind taking a look at our config? If so, what would be the appropriate channel?
I don't have any tricks there, but I'll retry it for you now. @jihoonson is trying to make it more reliable in #5077, at least.

Could you please elaborate a bit about what kinds of queries you can't get good performance using v2?

groupBy v1 had a bunch of shortcomings due to its use of IncrementalIndex (in fact, in the unit tests, a number of them are disabled for v1 since they can't pass). It's possible this issue is another of those problems with v1. And v2 is faster in all the tests we had done while developing it. So if you have a case where v2 is slower than v1, I'd like to understand it and improve v2.
I think it's primarily not being able to cache on the broker. We use mMemcached and see huge differences in query times (sub-second vs +30s) between v1 with broker cache and v2 without
If it helps: We run a very small cluster with only 3-6 historical nodes (r3.large).
Hmm, instead of the null check, I think it'd be better to use `Granularities.ALL` if none is provided. I expect that the vast majority of the time, that's what a user would want.

>> given 99% of the time the answer from memcached is going to be "not found"

seeing how this is the case, wouldn't it make sense to implement a local negative-cache to prevent the frequent calls to a remote cache?
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Negative_cache
One could reuse the existing local cache functionality to keep track of remote cache misses too.
To my understanding the current hybrid cache uses L1 only for positive caching.
@sascha-coenen when hybrid cache doesn't try to get a value from remote cache, when it's not found in the local cache, it already looks like "negative cache".

> I did look at that, specifically the AppenderatorPlumber. I opted not to use it because it wasn't really being used in any of the existing code paths and since I'm not as familiar with the code base, I thought it best to use the code thats been battle-tested, so to speak

That is right, the AppenderatorPlumber is not used anywhere -- it was meant to be a bridge from the (old) Plumber interface to the (newer) Appenderator layer but it never actually got linked anywhere. Mostly because I thought it would make more sense to port over the callers (like RealtimeIndexTask) to directly use an AppenderatorDriver. Does that look like it would work for you?

If so, I think that'd be the cleanest thing -- it would lead to eventually just removing Plumbers completely.

> Are you saying that the on-disk directory structures between the RealtimePlumber and the AppenderatorDriver are different?

That is what I'm saying. They are similar but slightly different, enough that they aren't compatible. You can see it if you run both code paths side by side, or if you look at the differences in bootstrapping code in the respective startJob methods.

> I don't have a strong opinion on whats best here in terms of preserving that so I'll defer to you on that.

If the task could do a migration of the older structure to the newer structure when starting up, I think that's best. It would just run one time but it would make people's lives easier when upgrading.
